awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Plant Biology and Conservation Research Experiences for Undergraduates--From Genes to Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Chicago Botanic Garden, located in Glencoe, IL, will support the training of 30 undergraduate students over the three summers from 2018- 2020. This plant biology program introduces undergraduates to research aimed at understanding the ecology, evolution, and human impacts on plants and fungi, with work spanning from genetic to ecosystem scales of analysis. The program has two goals: 1) investigate plant ecology and restoration in human-dominated landscapes, and 2) inspire and educate new researchers to move the field forward while engaging and communicating with a broad audience within and beyond the scientific community. Students apply for the program online, and graduate student and faculty mentors are responsible for interviewing and selecting the students that match well in the program.

It is anticipated that the 30 students will primarily be from schools with limited research opportunities, who have not participated in REU or similar experiences in the past, and/or are from groups traditionally underrepresented in the biological sciences. Students will learn how research is conducted, engage in an array of training activities, conduct near-peer mentoring of Chicago Public high school students, and present the results of their work at a public symposium. They will also produce a short video about their research that is accessible to a broad audience and posted on the Garden's YouTube channel. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://cbgreu.org, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Andrea Kramer at akramer@chicagobotanic.org) or the co-PI (Dr. Jeremie Fant at jfant@chicagobotanic.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Chicago Botanic Garden?s REU Site program has operated for 15 years, with the organizing theme of integrating the study, management, and conservation of plants and fungi. Operating in partnership with the graduate program in Plant Biology and Conservation, a joint program between the Chicago Botanic Garden (CBG) and Northwestern University, the CBG REU Site program has a key aim of enhancing the diversity and capacity of the botanical research community. Increasing the number of people working in botany-related professions is critical for addressing ongoing and future challenges with respect to the conservation of species and ecosystems. It is particularly important to train conservation professionals in botany, given the bias in funding opportunities that favors animal over plant conservation projects. The Chicago Botanic Garden, through its research and education programs, is relatively uniquely positioned to provide these training opportunities. Over the past 15 years, we have trained a diverse group of botanical researchers in plant conservation research, practice, and communication.

 Internships at CBG comprise 10 weeks that, in addition to the core research training, provide professional development, trainings in mentorship and science communication, and opportunities to build professional networks. The focus of the CBG REU Site is to advance understanding of plants and fungi and develop improved strategies for their conservation. Interns conduct research ranging from fundamental questions in plant evolution to developing tools for improving the effectiveness of ecological restoration. Our interns use study sites located at CBG, elsewhere in the Chicago region, and far beyond, with work that encompasses molecular, organismal, population, community, landscape, and ecosystem levels of analysis. Each participant develops an independent research project in consultation with a faculty mentor and a graduate student co-mentor. Students are then introduced to the research process, from question-generation through design, implementation, and analysis; throughout the summer, they gain skills in advanced field, lab, and analytical methods. Interns also participate in a weekly professional development workshop, where they are exposed to topics such as advanced data analysis, science ethics, and strategies for applying to graduate school.

 This REU Site program is an integral part of the Science Career Continuum at CBG that provides training in botany and conservation from pre-K to Ph.D. level students. As a part of this continuum, interns are not only mentored, but also serve as a mentor to high school students that participate in CBG?s College First program. This experience in a near-peer mentorship model helps build the confidence of REU participants, where mentors who are closer in age may be more accessible and serving as a mentor allows the interns to take on the role of expert. A core of this REU Site is increase the participation of students who identify as belonging to groups historically excluded from STEM fields. One way in which we worked towards this goal was to revise our application and evaluation website to reduce implicit bias in the selection process. Over the past 15 years we have achieved a more than three-fold increase in the participation of students belonging to historically excluded groups, with a mean of 80% for the 2018-2021 program. Participants in the program reported an increase in their confidence and identification of scientists, co-authored manuscripts, presented results at local and national meetings, and developed robust professional networks that have led to post-graduate opportunities in STEM fields.
